concept.title: Kitchen rules
concept.shortdesc: Pickleball's rules against close volleys are among the most numerous of any racquet sport.

conbody.p: The kitchen is sometimes called the non-volley zone. It is the space within 7 feet on both sides of the net.

p.b: You cannot volley while standing in the kitchen for any reason.

conbody.p: USAPA, the governing body of American pickleball, keeps an exhaustive list of what does and does not constitute a kitchen fault. For sake of simplicity, we boil them down to five rules.

p.b: A kitchen fault IS committed when:

ol.li: the volleying player has even one foot in the kitchen and/or on the kitchen line.
momentum carries the volleying player, or anything they are wearing/carrying, into the kitchen.
a player touches the kitchen right after volleying, even if the ball is declared dead beforehand.

p.b: A kitchen fault IS NOT committed when:

ol.li: there is no volley. So long as the ball bounces before you hit it, you can stand in the kitchen at any time.
the ball is over the kitchen AND you are not standing in the kitchen. Remember that the kitchen is a 2D "rectangle," not a 3D "box."
